content: Look alive out there this morning, because it’s looking like a big day for stocks. The Dow has busted out to a new record near 26,000 as traders come back from the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday, seemingly eager to dive back into this rally. It’s the opposite for bitcoin and cryptocurrencies, which may be in the throes of a “Black Monday”-style selloff: We’re kicking off with the chart of the day, which is timely as several tech stocks like Netflix NFLX, +3.35%  and Amazon AMZN, +1.11% are making headway this morning. The subject of that chart is one investor favorite — Apple AAPL, +0.78%  , which broke out to a new all-time high on Friday of $177.09. The chart comes from MKM Partners’ chief market technician, Jonathan Krinsky: MKM Partners/Bloomberg Apple may have just ignited its chances of becoming the first trillion-dollar company, driven by a strong trend and momentum, points out Krinsky in a note to clients. Krinsky notes that in Friday’s action, 33% of the S&P 500 components hit a 52-week high — the most in nearly five years. He warns this often means some kind of short-term pullback for stocks. And that’s where Apple comes in. He says it’s one stock that still has potential to run higher, even given the strong leg-up equities have experienced so far this year. Focus on “strong long-term trends that have been in near-term consolidations, and therefore are not short-term overbought,” Krinsky advises. content: Norges Bank Investment Management, the arm of Norway's central bank that manages the country's $1.1 trillion oil fund, said Tuesday that it has excluded a further nine companies from the fund on ethical grounds. Among those excluded is U.K. weapons maker BAE Systems PLC because of its involvement in the production of nuclear weapons. Data from the end of 2016, the latest available, shows that the oil fund held a 1.47% stake in BAE Systems. AECOM, Fluor Corp. and Huntington Ingalls Industries Inc. have also been excluded for the same reason, while Honeywell International Inc.'s exclusion is maintained based on this criterion, it said. The Norwegian Ministry of Finance has issued specific guidelines for the oil fund with criteria for observation and exclusion endorsed by Norway's parliament. These criteria say the fund must not invest in companies which produce weapons that violate fundamental humanitarian principles through their normal use, produce tobacco, or sell weapons or military material to certain countries. Companies may also be excluded if there is an unacceptable risk of conduct that is considered grossly unethical. Norges Bank decides on the exclusion of companies from the fund's investments, or to place them on an observation list. Further exclusions announced Tuesday include Evergreen Marine Corp (Taiwan) Ltd, Korea Line Corp., Precious Shipping PCL and Thoresen Thai Agencies PCL due to the "risk of severe environmental damage and serious or systematic violations of human rights." Pan Ocean Co. has been placed under observation based on the same criteria while Atal SA has also been excluded due to unacceptable risk of serious or systematic violations of human rights, Norges Bank said. There are currently over 140 companies excluded from the fund and around 20 under observation. -Write to Dominic Chopping at dominic.chopping@wsj.com; Twitter: @domchopping @WSJNordics More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? content: LOS ANGELES — Infrastructure and engineering firm Aecom is acquiring Shimmick Construction Company Inc. for $175 million, expanding its reach in the Western U.S. in anticipation of hundreds of billions of dollars in infrastructure spending expected in the coming years. Oakland, Calif.-based Shimmick has taken part in a number of infrastructure projects in the Western U.S., including improvements and repairs on the Golden Gate Bridge and public-transportation work in the San Francisco Bay Area and Honolulu. Aecom ACM, +2.59%   will take on the 27-year-old firm’s $1.35 billion project backlog, including a large project to replace a highway bridge near the Port of Long Beach. The Trump administration has proposed spending $200 billion over 10 years on infrastructure programs, with a goal of spurring a total of $1 trillion in financing with the inclusion of private investment. Those plans have fueled mergers and acquisitions in the infrastructure sector, as well as new interest from investors, including a planned $100 billion fund from Blackstone Group LP. In California and Washington, voters have passed ballot measures that call for nearly $180 billion in infrastructure investment, and the California legislature recently approved another $52 billion for road repairs. California’s infrastructure market is expected to grow in double digits annually for the next several years, and Aecom said it aims to capture as much of those funds as possible. content: President Trump says the Paris Agreement on climate change is bad for America. On Thursday, the president told a crowd in the White House Rose Garden, “It is time to put Youngstown, Ohio, Detroit, Michigan, and Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania — along with many, many other locations within our great country — before Paris, France.” Not everyone agrees. German Chancellor Angela Merkel called the decision “deeply regrettable” and said the deal to limit greenhouse emissions is critical to protect the planet and prevent further global warming. “We need this Paris accord to preserve our creation,” she said. “Nothing can and will stop us.” Even the mayor of Pittsburgh disagreed with Trump: Several other cities across the U.S. also vowed to uphold the agreement, despite Trump’s decision, including New York, Boston, Houston, Los Angeles, Philadelphia and Atlanta. (Here’s a full list of the so-called “Climate Mayors.” One of these mayors was accused of hypocrisy by some, though. When asked about his 12-mile trip from Gracie Mansion in Manhattan to his Park Slope, Brooklyn gym in his SUV, New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio said, “It doesn’t really have anything to do with how we change the world,” he said. “We change the world with policies that affect people.” Don’t miss: Bottled water is now more popular than soda — why you should avoid both But Jonathan Harrington, author of “The Climate Diet: How You Can Cut Carbon, Cut Costs, and Save the Planet,” says every little bit counts. In his book, he gives out various “awards” to people who try to make a difference in their own lives. A “participant” award goes to anyone who does anything (like separate plastics and paper in the trash), followed by bronze, silver and gold medals. “The Climate Diet is about making small incremental changes in the way you, your family or your community inhabits this planet,” he writes. So how do you recreate the Paris climate change accord at home? It’s far from simple. With that in mind, MarketWatch provides some suggestions: 1. Solar-power your home with and without panels This is one way to reduce your reliance on fossil fuels, but there’s a problem. Solar power “must get significantly less expensive” to expand to a level that would contribute meaningfully to global carbon-reduction goals, according to a report, “The New Solar System,” released in March by economists at Stanford University. “China and the United States find themselves at an unprecedented moment in the growth of solar power,” the report found. “How they proceed will do much to determine whether solar energy emerges as a mainstream energy source and, in the process, as an engine of significant economic growth and carbon reductions.” Several U.S. states recently passed legislation to support community solar, which gives homeowners the chance to use solar power without using solar panels. It’s not cheap to install solar panels. It costs between $10,045 and $13,475 after tax credits to install a solar panel on a roof, which works out at between $2.87 and $3.85 per watt, according to estimates by green energy website EnergySage. However, that’s still 9% lower than a year ago, it added. Another low-cost option: Harness solar power without the actual roof panels. Several U.S. states recently passed legislation to support community solar, which gives homeowners the chance to use solar power by leasing or subscribe to a solar panel power source. The National Renewable Energy Laboratory, a Colorado-based government institution that conducts research and development in renewable energy and energy efficiency, estimates that almost half (49%) of U.S. households would like to go solar, but don’t have the kind of roof that would support solar power. And there are approximately 15.8 million homes in the U.S. that have the potential to go solar, according to GTM Research, the research arm of energy media company Greentech Media. —Quentin Fottrell 2. Watch your thermostat and shut off your lights If you can’t get solar panels installed on your roof, never fear — there are other options. Shutting off the lights, using energy-efficient appliances and keeping the thermostat not too high or low could also help reduce your carbon footprint at home, according to Carbon Offsets to Alleviate Poverty, a 501(c)(3) charity dedicated to reducing carbon emissions. Turning off a light or turning off the television when you leave the room reduces greenhouse gas emissions by 0.15 pounds per hour. Lighting uses about 25% of all electricity in the country, the Office of Sustainability at Tufts University in Medford, Mass., said. Turning off a light or turning off the television when you leave the room reduces greenhouse gas emissions by 0.15 pounds per hour, according to Boston University, which calculated that if everyone at the school turned off the light for one hour a day for an entire year, they’d save enough energy to match the equivalent of taking 97 cars off the road for a year. Also see: 1 in 4 deaths of children under the age of 5 are due to unhealthy environments Additionally, using a compact fluorescent bulb as opposed to a regular bulb will prevent thousands of pounds of carbon dioxide, and they last 10 times longer (so you save money, too), according to Tufts. The same method applies to thermostats — keeping your thermostat two degrees higher in the winter and two degrees lower in the summer could save 2,000 pounds of carbon dioxide per year, estimates by Oregon’s Clackamas County found. As for appliances, products with the Environmental Protection Agency’s Energy Star label support energy efficiency. These appliances, which range across numerous categories including washing machines and air purifiers, have reduced greenhouse gas emissions by more than 2.4 billion metric tons and saved Americans more than $362 billion on utility bills over the last 22 years, according to the EPA’s Energy Star site. —Alessandra Malito 3. Don’t paint your roof green, paint it white Wait, what? While a blue bathroom might score you money when you sell your house, painting your roof a certain hue will win points with Mother Earth — and also save you money. It’s not as crazy as it sounds. The simple step of painting your roof white helps reflect sunlight, which keeps the entire building cooler and can slash your power bill by 30%, say advocates with The White Roof Project. That may also help cut down on pricey air-conditioning bills in the summer months, which some estimates put at $120 per month (or more) for the average home. On top of that, the pale roofs help cut smog, because they lower the air temperature, which traps less pollution in our skies, according to The White Roof Project. The organization says painting 5% of rooftops worldwide would cut 24 billion metric tons of carbon dioxide by 2034. And although it seems counter-intuitive, the white roof fix is three times more effective in fighting climate change than planting a green roof — the practice of covering a roof with grass and plants — researchers at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory found. But before you climb a ladder and slap a coat of white paint on your roof, check to make sure you’re using one with the proper reflective properties. —Leslie Albrecht 4. Car-share or just take public transportation Around 2.2 million U.S. workers have a daily commute of at least an hour to and from work, according to the “American Community Survey” by the U.S. Census, and 600,000 full-time workers are so-called super-commuters, spending 90 minutes and traveling 50 miles to get to work every day. The summertime is even worse for traffic: More than 80% of people who traveled 50 or more miles away from home over the Memorial Day Weekend — 34.6 million people — were on the roads. While coal-fired power plants are the biggest sources of greenhouse gases in the U.S., personal transportation comes in second and accounts for 20% of all greenhouse gas emissions. While coal-fired power plants are the biggest sources of greenhouse gases in the U.S., personal transportation comes in second and accounts for 20% of all greenhouse gas emissions, according to Rob Perks, transportation campaign director at the Natural Resources Defense Council, a non-profit environmental advocacy group based in Washington, D.C. If 25% of the population adopted new driving behaviors like carpooling, greenhouse gas emissions could be cut by 3% to 12%, saving billions of gallons of fuel, and resulting in potential savings of billions of dollars each year in gas, the Natural Resources Defense Council study found. When one person commutes in a car, it doesn’t just add to carbon emissions, it’s also costly. The Natural Resources Defense Council found that commuters spend $2,180 a year on maintaining a car and paying for gas to get to and from work in urban areas and $3,347 in the suburbs, while rural commuters spend $4,272 a year. Those who don’t commute to work only spend $1,857 a year. —Quentin Fottrell 5. Stick to one bag for your groceries (forever) There’s no easy answer for some domestic environmental decisions. California banned stores from giving out free plastic, single-use bags last November, making it the first such state-wide ban at grocery checkout lines. Dozens of other cities around the country have also banned what environmentalists say have been the scourge of oceans for decades. In California, consumers have to pay at least 10 cents for a plastic bag provided by the supermarket or bring their own reusable bag to the store and, in several cities consumers must pay 10 cents to buy a paper bag (Los Angeles did so in 2014). Studies say the most common replacements for single-use plastic grocery bags — paper and reusable bags — come with environmental and financial costs of their own. The widespread use of single-use carry-out plastic bags raises significant environmental concerns, according to a 2010 report by professional technical-services company Aecom Technology Corp. ACM, +2.59% It cited the short and long term adverse effects to marine ecosystems, solid waste management, global resource consumption and litter. Many major retailers sell reusable bags in biodegradable canvas, plastic or “bioplastics” manufactured from natural materials, but some big-box retailers sell alternative bags that are made from plastic and shipped from as far afield as China, 7,000 miles away. Experts say their most common replacements — paper and reusable bags — come with environmental and financial costs of their own. Paper bags are biodegradable, but some experts say cutting down trees is no answer either. And some reusable bags need to be used over 100 times before they’re better for the environment than single-use plastic bags. Polyethylene bags need to be used four times, a polypropylene bag must be used at least 11 times, and a cotton bag must be used at least 131 times, according to a study by the U.K. Environment Agency. —Quentin Fottrell 6. Recycle, and be mindful of what you throw out Next time you get take-out or delivery, consider throwing some of that garbage in recyclables — you’d at least be helping to save the planet. In this case, every little bit does help: One ton of papers recycled saves 17 trees from being cut down, according to Do It Green, a Minnesotan sustainable living all-volunteer group — it also takes up 65% less energy than producing paper from scratch. Read also: The CDC issues warning about a nasty chlorine-resistant parasite lurking in swimming pools Recycling and waste reduction benefit the environment and reduce humans’ carbon footprint in a number of ways: it slows down deforestation (trees also breathe in carbon dioxide), lessens the energy required to manufacture various products (manufacturing recyclables still requires energy, but far less than what’s necessary to create items out of raw materials) and avoids emissions that come from landfills, according to the University of Michigan. The U.S. in particular recycles 32% of its waste, which is similar to removing almost 40,000 cars from the road. Building up landfills is partially preventable, and avoiding it would save the earth from products, like plastic, from remaining in those landfills for centuries. More than 250 million tons of solid waste were accumulated in the U.S. in 2014 — composed of food (21%), plastics (18%), paper (14%) and rubber, leather and other textiles (10%), the Environmental Protection Agency concluded. —Alessandra Malito 7. Lobby your school to stop using foam cafeteria trays School cafeteria lunches are often a nutritional nightmare for kids’ diets, and experts say the foam trays they’re served on aren’t much better for the planet’s health. They’re made of petroleum, they can’t be recycled and therefore clog landfills, and disposing of them with garbage trucks creates greenhouse gas emissions, according to Cafeteria Culture, a group that advocates for removing the foam trays from schools. Despite their toll on the environment, the trays are popular with school districts because they’re cheap — only 3.5 cents compared with a 15-cent eco-friendly alternative. Don’t miss: This is how most Americans would like to die Bad news for “Climate Mayors” like Bill de Blasio, New York City Mayor. His SUV ride to the gym pales in comparison to what schools in New York and elsewhere did in 2015. The school systems in five major cities including New York and Los Angeles banded together to replace the foam trays with ones made of compostable and biodegradable material. By buying in bulk — the school districts ordered 271 million at once — the districts lowered the cost to just 4 cents a tray. Parents who want to take similar steps in their local schools can get in touch with Cafeteria Culture for ideas on how to convince officials to make the switch., or some schools are even wealthy enough to buy their own replacement trays. —Leslie Albrecht 8. Bike to work and advocate for greener transportation Biking is a direct route to lowering carbon emissions. In fact, if more people biked instead of drove to work, it would save $25 trillion globally by 2050 and cut carbon emissions by 10%, a 2015 study from the University of California-Davis and the Institute for Transportation and Development Policy in New York found. Currently about 6% of miles traveled in world cities is by bike, most of which comes from bike-friendly countries including Japan, China, the Netherlands and Denmark. In the U.S., only 1% of urban trips are made by bike. Experts say this number could be a lot higher: 35% of trips American commuters make are less than 5 kilometers (3 miles), or easily covered in a 20-minute bike ride. Around 35% of trips American commuters make are less than 5 kilometers (3 miles), or easily covered in a 20-minute bike ride. However, not all cities in the U.S. are bike-friendly, and biking advocates say that won’t change unless more citizens get involved. Nonprofit People for Bikes suggests attending community input meetings and building partnerships with businesses to lobby for bike lanes and other safety measures in their communities. As of 2014, there were bike lanes in 24 states and 53 cities and cities like Los Angeles have created recent policy shifts toward cutting car lanes and adding bike and bus lanes instead. —Kari Paul World Leaders Condemn Trump Climate Decision 9. Embrace dietary changes and skip avocado toast Bad news: Saving the environment may mean skipping that avocado toast. Skyrocketing demand (and prices) for avocados has driven farmers toward illegally cutting down trees in rain forests across Mexico, according to The Guardian newspaper in the U.K. In total, roughly 1,700 acres of forests were lost as a result of increased avocado production in the Mexican state of Michoacan alone, researchers predict. From cutting avocados out to avoiding products with palm oil (another product that has caused deforestation around the globe), choosing to eat a sustainable diet is another way to protect against climate change. Meat products are far and away the worst food products when it comes to the greenhouse gases stemming from their production, transportation and consumption, data from the Environmental Working Group found. Lamb is the worst culprit, causing 39.2 kilograms of carbon dioxide emissions for every kilogram eaten. Comparatively, lentils produce less than 1 kilogram of carbon dioxide for every kilogram eaten. See Meat Eater’s Guide to Climate Change + Health for more. —Jacob Passy 10. Stay green at the office and unplug your computer We know office design can improve concentration, but did you know it can also help the environment? Interior decorators are increasingly incorporating living walls into corporate office spaces to naturally cool offices during summer months and improve air quality. Even if you don’t have a hand in office planning, there are many measures you can take at your own desk to help the environment. Use power strips rather than individual plugs and invest in power-saving electronic devices for your desk. Also, don’t forget the basics: Turn off the lights, unplug electronics, and shut down your computer when you leave for the day. —Kari Paul 11. Avoid the SUV and, if you must, take nonstop flights Where travelers go and how they get there can be a significant source of pollution. And when it comes to vacationing, air travel is one of the worst culprits. Aircraft produce up to 2.5% of total global carbon dioxide emissions, according to data from the Centre for Aviation, Transport and the Environment at Manchester Metropolitan University http://www.cate.mmu.ac.uk/projects/bridging-the-aviation-co2-emissions-gap-why-emissions-trading-is-needed/ . That rate would make the aviation industry one of the world’s 10 largest carbon dioxide emitters, if it were a country, according to the Environmental Defense Fund. Taking a solo road trip in an SUV produces roughly 60% more greenhouse gases than your portion of a plane’s greenhouse gas emissions on a flight the same distance. While flying is bad for the environment, driving can be even worse. Taking a solo road trip in an SUV produces roughly 60% more greenhouse gases than your portion of a plane’s greenhouse gas emissions on a flight the same distance, per data from the Sightline Institute, a policy research non-profit based in Seattle. The best ways to travel include taking motor coaches or trains. If flying is a necessity, there are ways to make a smaller impact on the environment. Because first-class seats take up roughly twice the amount of space, someone flying in coach accommodations is responsible for about half the carbon emissions, a report from the Union of Concerned Scientists concluded. Similarly, choosing a non-stop flight is better for the environment (even if it’s worse for your wallet) because takeoff, landing and taxiing to and from the terminal uses so much energy. The Union of Concerned Scientists estimated that a 1,000-mile nonstop flight from New York City to Orlando saves nearly 35% the carbon emissions versus a two-connection flight itinerary. —Jacob Passy More from Dow Jones Media Six ways ‘Working Girl’ taught us to work it A former banker’s disillusionment with British politics Signet Jewelers Is Up to Its Neck With Bad News SMARTASSET.COM

content: We have such a short attention span as investors. Not only did Wall Street fully price in the effect of a Donald Trump presidency in two months across November and December last year, but apparently some investors are already giving up on the “Trump trade” before the president’s first 100 days are up. The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.07%   has dropped 3.1% through Thursday since closing at a record on March 1, although it is still up 11.6% since Election Day. The S&P 500 SPX, +1.38%   has dropped 2.8% from its record close on March 1, trimming post-election gains to 8.85%. Perhaps more tellingly of what the fast money is doing, financial stocks have skidded more than 8% since March 1. You can blame old saws like “buy the rumor, sell the news.” Or you can blame newfangled distractions like a cellphone video showing a passenger being dragged off a flight and the nonstop news cycle of outrage that follows. Read: The stock market will be stuck in ‘purgatory’ until this happens But let’s not be too hasty. Like it or not, Donald Trump has four years in the White House and Republicans are still in control of both houses of Congress. We are a long way from the end of the Trump era. And while there have admittedly been setbacks and surprises, investors still should be looking to Washington for cues in 2017. Here’s what I expect to happen in the coming months based on the initial actions under President Trump and how Wall Street will embrace a new version of the “Trump trade”: Defense stocks should rise amid Mideast unrest I’ve been appalled for years at the staggering scale of the humanitarian crisis in Syria. But moralizing never seems to get me anywhere, particularly in the age of Trump, so let’s skip right to the trade: defense stocks. Picks like Raytheon Co. RTN, +2.26%   that manufacturer the Tomahawk missiles launched last week are top-of-mind, but don’t forget that the broader Trump budget proposal was heavy on defense — including specific calls to boost the F-35 stealth fighter program run by Lockheed Martin Corp. LMT, +0.78%   and production of other jet fighters and sub-hunting aircraft manufactured mainly by Boeing Co. BA, +2.46%  . In light of recent airstrikes and the support Trump has won among hawkish Republicans as a result, it seems highly unlikely that spending like this will be on the chopping block. Keep in mind, too, that the start of a conflict can be a big boost to these picks regardless of whether the conflict is deemed proper or popular in the long-term. After the Iraq “shock and awe” campaign at the end of March 2003, Raytheon surged 24% in two months and Boeing leapt about 20%. Here's how drones will change the future of warfare Tech companies can juice their buybacks with repatriation tax breaks It’s old news how much cash tech stocks have lying around overseas, but I’ll revisit the math for you. In its 2016 annual report, Microsoft Corp. MSFT, +2.10%     reported $113.2 billion in cash, but 83% of that was held by foreign subsidiaries — meaning roughly $94 billion in overseas capital. If that was hit by current taxes by a maximum of 35%, that shrinks to “only” $61 billion. But if Trump gets his way with a tax repatriation holiday rate of around 10%, Microsoft will have access to almost $85 billion. I’m not naive enough to presume that extra $24 billion in tax savings will go to jobs or factories, but you can be sure it will juice buybacks and prompt a special dividend that lifts Microsoft stock. The same is true for other firms such as Apple Inc. AAPL, +0.78% Cisco Systems Inc. CSCO, +2.95%  and International Business Machines Corp. IBM, +0.60%  . Construction firms will benefit from bipartisan infrastructure bill On balance, I’m pretty skeptical of Trump’s ability to get anything done with a divided GOP in Congress and an even more divided electorate. However, I don’t buy the notion that infrastructure spending is impossible just because it could be expensive. Polling of voters has shown strong support of infrastructure spending, and it’s one of the few areas where Democrats and moderate Republicans will agree. A recent “Infrastructure Report Card” from the American Society of Civil Engineers that gave our roads, bridges and waterways a collective grade of D+ underscores how the need is so great. Particularly after the Obamacare repeal-and-replace defeat and what I expect will be a disappointing push at comprehensive tax reform, infrastructure will be the path of least resistance for Trump to notch a policy win. That means firms like gravel giant Vulcan Materials Co. VMC, +2.58% machinery giant Caterpillar Inc. CAT, +1.53%  and transportation engineer AECOM ACM, +2.59%  should be decent bets. How 4D mapping could change the way we live and work Don’t forget energy infrastructure efforts While roads and wastewater systems spring to mind most often when we talk of infrastructure, let’s not forget the energy infrastructure that has become increasingly important in the age of fracking and tar sands in North America. The much-maligned Keystone XL pipeline proposed by TransCanada Corp. TRP, +2.63%  has gotten the most press, but there are other projects such as the Dakota Access Pipeline — under construction by Energy Transfer Partners LP ETP, +0.81%   — that have been helped by the administration. And with the focus on energy jobs and independence from foreign oil, you can be sure pipeline and storage companies including Magellan Midstream Partners LP MMP, +2.08%  or Enterprise Products Partners LP EPD, +1.75%  will benefit from less red tape and delays on future projects. U.S.-only companies look safer than the alternatives There’s admittedly plenty of wrangling around the defense budget, infrastructure and the other issues listed above. But whether it’s a tax break or stimulus to help American consumers, or a trade war or literal military conflict that affects multinationals, one thing is clear: Trump’s nationalist worldview will always favor U.S. businesses. That ultimately may wind up being a net negative in the long run, but it’s the way things are. Furthermore, with Brexit to China’s slowing growth to conflict in Syria to missile launches in North Korea … well, there are plenty of reasons to be wary about investing abroad. Thus, consumer plays like Southwest Airlines Co. LUV, +1.83% or Macy’s Inc. M, +2.30% both of which generate almost every penny of revenue within the U.S., may be noteworthy. The same is true for business-facing companies like Paychex Inc. PAYX, +1.63%  or CBIZ Inc. CBZ, +0.00%  that almost exclusively serve American clients. content: I can safely say that, from my 35 years in the financial markets, to be consistently successful at investing, one must put prudence over popularity. Human nature as it is, investors often find it difficult to take unpopular actions. My motivation in writing this column is to nudge you to take five unpopular, but prudent, actions today. But before I do that, let’s look at two charts and understand the concept of “over-owned.” Two charts The charts compare five currently over-owned stocks in five sectors of the S&P 500 Index SPX, +1.38% The first is a daily chart of the period since Donald Trump's election. If you are uninitiated in inter-market analysis, these charts may at first seem intimidating. I suggest you look at them for a few minutes, and you will see several insights jumping out at you. Over-owned Some readers may say that the five stocks listed above have good fundamentals and technicals. The unpopular, but prudent, action, however, is to take some profits now that the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.07%  is close to an expensive 20,000 points. "If both fundamentals and technicals are good, why take partial profits?" might be the question. The answer lies in an important concept that some investors and analysts tend to ignore at their own peril. The concept can be best described by one word: "over-owned." In the simplest terms, stocks go up when there are more buyers than sellers. What happens when almost everyone who is going to buy a stock has already bought it? The answer: There is no fuel to propel the stock upward. As an example, The Arora Report gave a “sell” signal right at the peak before Apple AAPL, +0.78%  fell by over $300 pre-split. One key component of our algorithms that made the call was over-ownership. (This call can be easily verified if you have been a subscriber to The Arora Report or by reading MarketWatch.) Sell popular infrastructure stocks Infrastructure stocks are flying high. On the surface it makes a lot of sense. Trump plans to build a wall on the Mexican border and has been emphasizing improving infrastructure throughout the U.S. It’s important to note that infrastructure stocks were also Hillary Clinton stocks. A favorite Wall Street thesis was to buy infrastructure stocks as it was deemed a winning proposition irrespective of who won the election. As a result, the stocks were overbought going into the election, and now that the election is over, are becoming even more overbought. Furthermore, these stocks are expensive both relative to their own histories and their projected earnings growth rates. Examples of infrastructure stocks are Martin Marietta, Vulcan Materials VMC, +2.58% Granite Construction GVA, +4.67% Tetra Tech TTEK, +1.24% Fluor FLR, +2.45% KBR KBR, +3.58% United Rentals URI, +2.14% Aecom ACM, +2.59% Terex TEX, +2.13% and Manitowoc MTW, +3.87% These stocks should be avoided, but considered for purchase only in the event of a pullback. Sell popular pharmaceutical stocks Americans pay a lot more for drugs than people in other countries. That’s why you ought to sell large U.S.-based companies. After all, they are at risk of Trump tweets. Examples include, Pfizer, Johnson & Johnson JNJ, +0.55% Merck MRK, -1.13% Bristol-Myers Squibb BMY, +1.09% Abbott ABT, +1.16% and Eli Lilly LLY, +0.47% Sell popular utility stocks Utilities will benefit from deregulation, but higher interest rates will outweigh that. These popular stocks have become very over-owned and expensive. Examples include Duke Energy, Southern Co. SO, +0.04% NextEra NEE, +0.65% American Electric Power AEP, -0.10% PG&E PCG, +1.60% and Edison International EIX, +0.94% Trim dividend-paying stocks Dividend-paying stocks have been very popular and overowned. As a result they have become very expensive. They will be negatively impacted by rising interest rates. Examples include General Mills, Kellogg K, +1.74% Philip Morris PM, -0.39% Kimberly-Clark KMB, +0.61% Sysco SYY, +0.99% and Tupperware TUP, +2.33% Trim popular technology stocks Investors are oblivious that some popular technology stocks get a large portion of their sales from China. Examples include Nvidia, Broadcom AVGO, -0.44% Intel INTC, +5.00% Cisco CSCO, +2.95% IBM IBM, +0.60% and Oracle ORCL, +1.71% What to do now Some of the cash raised from sales described above should be deployed in less risky stocks and ETFs that are likely to do well. The construction company expects adjusted profit in 2017 in a range of $2.70 to $3.10 a share, compared with the consensus estimate from analysts of $3.24 a share, according to FactSet. A small position in gold and silver is fine, but taking on a huge position on Trump victory is not supported by hard data at this time. Bonds Wall Street is selling bonds on the assumption that Trump will be a big spender. Selling bonds based on the Trump victory ignores offsetting factors. The first is that the Federal Reserve is less likely to orchestrate a series of rate hikes after Trump victory. The second is that both Senate and House are now controlled by Republicans, including many deficit hawks. Trump himself is cognizant of the high national debt. Medicaid stocks Medicaid insurance stocks are being crushed on potential repeal of ObamaCare. Take a look at Molina Healthcare MOH, +2.64%  and Centene Corp CNC, +6.50% However, Trump has repeatedly stated that he is a compassionate man and those who cannot afford will be provided health care under his plan. Take a look at Foresight Energy FELP, +0.57% Cloud Peak Energy CLD, -9.35%  and Peabody Energy US:BTUUQ However, coal competes with natural gas and natural gas is simply too cheap. content: So you’re betting that Hillary Clinton will be sworn in as our 45th president in January. All investors should be pleased if this is the outcome. As I wrote a month ago, Donald Trump’s economic proposals would be detrimental to the stock market and downright dangerous for the U.S. economy. I was hardly alone in this sentiment, with a former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund warning of the risks of a Trump presidency recently, and the stock market suffering a nine-day stretch of declines — the longest such run since 1980 — on mere glimmers of hope for Trump. But forget Trump. While his plans were clearly bad for the economy, while he is a pathological liar, documented misogynist and not-so-closeted racist, going forward he should be now (mercifully) irrelevant to the markets SPX, +1.38%   and the course of the U.S. economy. Follow the MarketWatch live blog of election coverage as results roll in. Why Does the Stock Market Want Hillary? So let’s talk about what will matter — namely, what the global economy will look like under President Clinton and which stocks will succeed. Here’s what I think would make the perfect Hillary portfolio for 2017. Aecom The nation’s crumbling infrastructure is a sore point in many communities, and a big part of the Clinton campaign was a plan to invest $275 billion over five years in roads, rails and other projects. While multinational names like Caterpillar Inc. CAT, +1.53%   are frequently bandied about to play this trend, I prefer the midcap industrial Aecom ACM, +2.59% which generated over a third of its fiscal-year 2015 revenue from state, local and federal contracts here in the U.S. and 69% of total revenue from within America. This company is as direct a play as you’ll find on U.S. infrastructure spending, and after a $6 billion acquisition of rival URS in 2014, Aecom has plenty of scale and capacity to step up and profit from this trend. Read: Watch these dozen critical counties on Election Night 8Point3 Energy Partners Under President Barack Obama, energy regulations were very much against dirty sources like coal and in favor of cleaner sources like solar and natural gas. That would continue under President Clinton, and one of my favorite alternative energy plays for this trend is “yieldco” 8Point3 Energy Partners LP CAFD, +1.93% a partnership formed by giants First Solar Inc. FSLR, +2.39%  and SunPower Corp. SPWR, +4.18% 8Point3 doesn’t manufacture panels, but instead operates and acquires utility-scale projects to generate reliable cash flow and fuel a juicy 6% yield based on the past year of payouts. Fighting climate change and moving toward solar power will be a big part of a Hillary Clinton administration, and 8Point3 will generate big dividends and decent returns in the years ahead. Teva Pharmaceuticals If Clinton is in the White House and Democrats gain ground in the Senate, any assault on the Affordable Care Act is dead in the water. However, that doesn’t mean changes aren’t afoot — particularly after the recent hearings over Mylan N.V. MYL, +1.65%   price gouging with its EpiPen treatment. Read: Mylan earnings: what to expect Shrewd or lucky investors may be able to parse the winners and losers of Big Pharma’s looming fight with the White House and Democratic consumer advocates like Elizabeth Warren, but I’d rather just bank on the world’s largest generic drug manufacturer instead. Sure, Teva Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd. ADR TEVA, +0.29%   doesn’t quite make the margins of a sexy biotech company that has a high-price niche treatment. However, increased attention on what some see as predatory pricing of these very costly treatments will only open the door for more generic drug sales — and with roughly $20 billion in annual revenue, Teva is the worldwide leader in this space. Read: 3 potential health-care stock winners amid the rubble Lockheed Martin As a former secretary of state, our new president is sure to continue the fight against ISIS in earnest across 2017 and 2018. But she’ll continue that fight with a knowledge that the American people don’t have the stomach for many boots on the ground. That means increased reliance on drones and air assaults, which will benefit Lockheed Martin Corp. LMT, +0.78% This is one of the government’s favorite contractors, generating nearly $36 billion of its $46 billion-plus in total revenue from the U.S. government in FY2015. While military spending is always in the crosshairs, the cuts from recent years are unlikely to accelerate further — and even with a smaller pie, Lockheed is clearly getting a very big slice. Yes, there are risks for the stock, but a 3% dividend yield after a double-digit increase in payouts this fall helps you hedge your bets. Two Things to Watch on Election Night Tyson Foods In an age of heightened tensions around immigration, executives at Tyson Foods Inc. TSN, +0.36%  may have been mighty nervous lately. That’s because the poultry giant relies heavily on foreign-born workers and in fact was accused of actively recruiting illegal immigrants from Latin America more than a decade ago. Things have changed a lot in the intervening years, both for Tyson and for the political climate in America, and a more welcoming environment for immigrants will be a win-win both for workers who come to the U.S. for opportunity and employers like Tyson who rely heavily on unskilled foreign-born workers to keep things running. In short, Clinton’s pro-immigration policies will help Tyson keep labor costs down. Considering Tyson stock already has a bargain forward price-to-earnings ratio of about 14 compared with an average of almost 18 for S&P 500 stocks, that bodes very well for Tyson Foods. Read: How employers could stop illegal immigration in seconds Intermediate-Term Corporate Bond ETF Donald Trump’s attacks on the Federal Reserve hinted that he would push hard for an interest-rate hike, but Clinton has been much more circumspect about the central bank and reluctant to hasten a premature rate increase. So while we may see another interest-rate increase in December, chances are the Fed will remain relatively dovish on rates for the next year or so. Read: Fed’s Evans says not confident U.S. central bank will hit its 2% target That means the SPDR Bloomberg Barclays Intermediate Term Corporate Bond ETF US:ITR  is a good balance between long-term interest-rate risk and the anemic yields of short-term debt. With an average maturity of five years, ITR won’t be as exposed to the tail end of the yield curve, and investment-grade bonds instead of Treasurys give the fund a current yield of about 2.6% — significantly higher than the 1.8% yielded by 10-year T-notes. As the European Central Bank and Bank of Japan both pursue negative rates, it’s hard to imagine the Fed will diverge significantly from this trend, or that the rate picture will change under Hillary Clinton’s administration. What can artificial intelligence do for retail? Unilever Speaking of Europe and Japan, it’s worth taking a step back and getting a global economic perspective even as we talk about U.S. politics. Because as much as I thought Trump was cancerous for stocks and the global economy, I also think nobody can really drive significant growth with a hyperpartisan House of Representatives and a stagnant global outlook. That’s why I think it’s important to hedge your bets with London-based consumer staples giant Unilever PLC ADR UL, +0.83% ULVR, +1.02% UNA, +1.17% Unilever has mammoth brands including Lipton teas and Dove soaps that will prove recession-proof (if it comes to the “R” word). It’s a true multinational with operations in 190 countries and sales at home in Europe as well as in the U.S. and (increasingly) in emerging markets. As much as I would love to say that brighter days are ahead of us, investors need to be realistic and objective about stock-market valuations and macro risks in the next few years. Thus, it’s prudent to balance the tactical plays above with a globalized staples bet — because in 2017, you can’t build a wall around the U.S. economy, and you shouldn’t do so with your personal portfolio, either. content: Hillary Clinton triggered an uproar earlier this month when she grouped some of rival Donald Trump’s supporters into a “basket of deplorables.” But Deutsche Bank this week had a different type of basket in mind when it released its Clinton versus Trump trading strategies. “Our S&P targets and sector strategy assume a balanced outcome from the U.S. general election on Nov 8 that maintains the current split in power,” said David Bianco, an investment strategist at Deutsche Bank. Outgoing President Barack Obama is a Democrat; the House and Senate are controlled by Republicans. Bianco earlier this year had forecast the S&P 500 SPX, +1.38%  to close out 2016 at 2,150. A political landscape in which different parties divide up the presidency and the control of the Senate is likely to lead to more market volatility, according to the strategist. That the presidential candidates are unable to communicate their economic policies to the voting public is also contributing to the lack of clarity. “It’s difficult to pin down specific policies from either candidate but on several economic issues their general bias is clear” he said. Still, the investment strategist suggested several possible plays in case either party unexpectedly wins both the White House and Capitol Hill in November. As Bianco sees it, a Republican sweep led by Trump would be good for some oil producers by opening the way to more drilling. But it could also hurt some energy stocks as additional supply would weigh on prices. It could also result in faster interest rate increases and a stronger dollar. “If Fed hikes bring yield-curve flattening, then big banks and capital markets likely outperform small banks and insurance companies,” he said. Republican control of the executive and legislative branches would also translate into more pressure on corporations to repatriate their foreign earnings. U.S. multinationals like Apple Inc. A Democratic sweep, meanwhile, would likely to result in a push for a higher inflation target by the Fed, while trade, commodities, life insurers, and health care services sectors are expected to benefit. “Slow hikes that allow inflation to accelerate and steepen the curve might favor smaller banks and insurance, but this could pressure price-earnings [ratios] at non-financials,” he said. content: SINGAPORE—This wealthy financial center is known world-wide for its tidy streets and tight controls on personal behavior, including famous restrictions on the sale of chewing gum to keep the city clean. Now Singapore may soon be known for something else: the most extensive effort to collect data on daily living ever attempted in a city. As part of its Smart Nation program, launched by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong in late 2014, Singapore is deploying an undetermined number of sensors and cameras across the island city-state that will allow the government to monitor everything from the cleanliness of public spaces to the density of crowds and the precise movement of every locally registered vehicle. It is a sweeping effort that will likely touch the lives of every single resident in the country, in ways that aren’t completely clear since many potential applications may not be known until the system is fully implemented. Already, for instance, authorities are developing or using systems that can tell when people are smoking in prohibited zones or littering from high-rise housing. But the data collected in this next phase — and how it’s used — will go far beyond that. Much of the data will be fed into an online platform, dubbed Virtual Singapore, that will give the government an unprecedented look into how the country is functioning in real time, allowing them to predict, for example, how infectious diseases might spread or how crowds could react to an explosion in a shopping mall. The government also plans to share data, in some cases, with the private sector. Just looking Officials say the program is designed to improve government services through technology, better connect its citizens, and encourage private-sector innovations. For instance, sensors deployed by private companies in some elderly people’s publicly managed homes will alert family if they stop moving, and even record when they use the toilet in an attempt to monitor general health. Yet the government also says it isn’t certain what kinds of applications might be possible once the system is built, and hasn’t decided where all the sensors will be located, raising privacy concerns. A spokesman says that the government will only deploy sensors when there are specific benefits to citizens, and that it doesn’t set out to build systems and collect data before deciding what to do with it. Any decision to use data collected by Smart Nation sensors for law enforcement or surveillance would not, under Singapore law, need court approval or citizen consultation. If the network is somehow hacked, criminals could potentially access a trove of data about citizens’ lives. “The big, big elephant in the room is protection of privacy and ensuring security,” says Vivian Balakrishnan, Singapore’s foreign affairs minister and minister-in-charge of Smart Nation. “We don’t have the answers,” though the government is studying the issue and is dedicated to ensuring citizens maintain privacy, he says. The government hasn’t held a public discussion on the issue, but has said that data will be anonymized to the greatest extent possible, and that it already has measures in place to protect data it collects. The project appears to be popular in Singapore, where faith in the government is high and citizens have accepted limits on behavior, including restrictions on public speech and the press, in return for a more efficient state. “I trust the system here,” says Jerelyn Hew, 30, who works for a locally based online-learning company, when asked her opinion about Smart Nation during lunch. Hew says she looks forward to benefits such as easier parking. Other cities, such as New York and Barcelona, have used sensors and computer networks to analyze such things as residents’ sleeping patterns and availability of parking spots. But those projects are typically narrow in scope and often siloed in individual agencies or research bodies. Singapore’s program is highly centralized. The various projects are coordinated by a Smart Nation bureau in Prime Minister Lee’s office, which works with relevant government bodies on ideas. About a dozen trial projects have been launched so far, with many targeted for wider implementation. The total cost is undisclosed. AFP/Getty Images Authorities are developing or using systems that can tell when people are smoking in prohibited zones or littering from high-rise housing “Singapore is doing it at a level of integration and scale that no one else has done yet,” says Guy Perry, an executive of the Los Angeles engineering design firm Aecom ACM, +2.59% who studies “smart city” technologies. It helps in Singapore that government- or state-owned companies own or control many aspects of daily life, including public transport networks and housing. More than 80% of Singapore’s 5.5 million people live in government housing. And while Singapore is a democracy, it has always been dominated by a single party whose control of the system means it can move quickly. Leaders also see a chance to pioneer applications for export. The market for smart-city technology in Asia alone will reach US$1 trillion a year by 2025, according to IDC Government Insights, a unit of International Data Corp., the Framingham, Mass., research firm. Crystal ball The centerpiece of Singapore’s effort is a kind of digital crystal ball that acts as a superpowered, X-ray version of Google Maps. Sensor data will be fed into this system, which will store exact dimensions of buildings, placement of windows and types of construction materials used. The system is being built by the government’s National Research Foundation, in coordination with private-sector firms, universities and other government departments. The government has already published a 2-D online map of Singapore that allows the public to see current closed-circuit TV footage, check flooding levels and monitor open spaces in parking lots. Officials say the data-packed map will help them better decide where to reroute buses based on where riders are gathering. It could also be used to model how new skyscrapers might affect wind-flow patterns or telecommunications signals, or map the potential spread of infectious diseases into buildings. When such huge volumes of data are collected and cross-referenced, experts say, applications emerge that are difficult to imagine until the material is available in the first place. “It is a little bit of a build-and-they-will-come approach,” says Tim Greisinger, managing director of International Business Machines Corp. IBM, +0.60% in Singapore, whose firm is developing some technology used in Smart Nation. “What could you do once you have it?” he wonders, referring to the national network of sensors. “The opportunities are endless.” Other new Smart Nation technologies that have been tested include the cameras that detect when people are smoking in prohibited zones — useful for a city that is serious about policing such behavior. As part of routine enforcement last year, unrelated to Smart Nation, the government said it fined a 38-year-old man roughly $14,000 after he was caught repeatedly throwing cigarette butts out of his high-rise apartment. He was photographed shirtless by security cameras, and images of his transgression were posted on the website of Singapore’s environmental agency. Singapore has also tested systems using citizens’ smartphones to measure the bumpiness of bus rides, which could indicate road maintenance requirements. Other initiatives include mandatory satellite-linked devices that will be placed in all Singapore-registered vehicles — including those of private citizens — to charge tolls more precisely, based on precise distances driven. It also would permit dynamic pricing throughout the day, depending on road conditions. Sensors for the elderly Then there is the elderly resident monitoring program, which started on a trial basis in 2014 and is voluntary. The sensors measure movements in the home. The data is handled by private companies selected by the government. It can be accessed, with family members’ permission, by caregivers. Although free for trial participants, the thinking is that residents would pay for the service in the future. Doris Oo says she has used the system when leaving her 79-year-old mother at home alone in the apartment they share. She got text messages when her mother’s movements changed, suggesting potential illness or distress. “It was really peace of mind,” Oo says. She says that she is eager to participate in an expanded effort set to launch soon — and that neither she nor her mother feel the technology is invasive. Jake Maxwell Watts and Newley Purnell are Wall Street Journal reporters in Singapore. They can be reached at jake.watts@wsj.com and newley.purnell@wsj.com. content: Aecom Technology Corp.'s ACM, +2.59% fiscal third-quarter earnings rose 1.9% as the technical and management-support services provider's margins improved despite weaker revenue. The company also lowered its full-year earnings estimate by 10 cents to a range of $2.30 to $2.40 a share, citing further deterioration in its Australia mining business and slower conversion of backlog in the Americas. Aecom's revenue from professional technical-services has been challenged by slow global economic growth, especially in Australia and the Americas. But demand for its management-support services had improved in recent quarters, driven by growth in the Middle East. For the quarter ended June 30, Aecom reported a prof it of $70.8 million, or 70 cents a share, up from $69.4 million, or 63 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue declined 1.3% to $2.07 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had most recently forecast per-share earnings of 64 cents on revenue of $2.1 billion. Gross margin improved to 6.4% from 5.3%. Revenue from the professional-technical-services segment was essentially flat at $1.85 billion and revenue from management-support services declined 11% to $220.4 million. content: Aecom Technology Corp. ACM, +2.59% swung to a fiscal fourth-quarter loss as the company was hit by a large goodwill impairment charge, while professional technical services segment revenue slipped. For the current year, Aecom said it expects per-share earnings between $2.40 to $2.50, below the $2.57 expected by analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Chief Executive John M. Dionisio noted that the view "reflects continued pressure on growth as a result of the global macro-economic climate." For the fourth quarter, Aecom recorded a non-cash goodwill impairment charge of $2.88 a share, or $317 million net of tax, related to its Europe business and its management support services unit, which provides services primarily for U.S. government agencies. Aecom said in Europe, the impairment charge resulted mainly from the negative impact of economic trends, which drove a reduction in profit levels. Meanwhile, it noted that the impairment in the management support services unit was "largely driven by the loss of revenue due to the precipitous drawdown of troops in Iraq during 2012." Still, Aecom said it expects that both its Europe and management support services businesses will show "strong growth in profitability" in the current fiscal year. For the quarter ended Sept. 30, Aecom reported a loss of $224.9 million, or $2.05 a share, versus a year-ago profit of $87.4 million, or 75 cents a share. Stripping out the goodwill impairment charge, Aecom reported a per-share profit of 83 cents. Revenue slipped 1.7% to $2.08 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters recently expected a per-share profit of 82 cents on revenue of $2.22 billion. Gross margin widened to 6.9% from 6.6%. Aecom said in its professional technical services segment, revenue fell 3.2% to $1.8 billion, as double-digit growth in Asia-Pacific was offset by the "challenging environment" in the U.S. and in Europe. Adjusted operating income increased 5.6% to $143 million for the segment. Meanwhile, in the smaller management support services segment, revenue rose 11% to $261 million, primarily due to a higher level of activity in Asia and the Middle East. Adjusted operating income however declined 35% to $12 million. Shares closed Monday at $21.76 and were inactive premarket. The stock has risen 15% in the past three months. content: WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) — Among the stocks that could see active trade in Friday’s session are Gyrodyne Co. of America, QEP Resources Inc. and Autodesk Inc. Madison Square Garden Co. MSG, +1.35%  is the only company of note scheduled to report financial results to close out the trading week. Gyrodyne GYRO, -0.82%  hired financial and legal parties for advice on how to go about maximizing shareholder value, the St. James, N.Y.-based a real estate investment trust said. Among the options to be explored are a potential sale, merger or other strategic combination as well as one or more potential cash distributions, according to Gyrodyne, which noted that there can be no assurance that any option will be ultimately adopted. The company also announced that Stephen Maroney resigned Aug. 16 as chief executive and president and that Chief Financial Officer Gary Fitlin has been named to fill the posts on an interim basis. Also late Thursday, QEP Resources QEP, +4.15%  said it struck a pair of agreements, with Black Hills Corp. BKH, +0.63%  and Unit Corp. UNT, +21.08% to acquire properties in North Dakota promising “significant crude-oil development.” Denver-based QEP paid about $1.38 billion cash in the transactions, which will give the company net daily production of about 10,500 barrels of oil equivalent as well as development opportunities near its existing core acreage in the Williston Basin. They’re expected to close on or before Sept. 27, the company said. QEP pegged net proved and probable reserves at about 125 million barrels of oil equivalent — 81% crude, 10% natural gas and 9% natural gas liquids. To reflect the additional properties, QEP raised its 2012 forecasts for adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization as well as for production and capital investment. For their part, Black Hill said it would use net proceeds of about $230 million to $240 million to pay down debt and help fund growth projects such as the Cheyenne Prairie Generating Station, while Unit said its deal with QEP is in keeping with plans to divest non-core assets. content: NEW DELHI (MarketWatch) -- U.S.-based engineering consultancy firm Aecom Technology Corp ACM, +2.59% is in talks with two or three Indian companies for a possible acquisition to expand its presence in India, a company executive said late Tuesday. "We are looking to buy one or more companies in the engineering and design consultancy business, especially those active in the transport and energy sectors," director for India Avinash Misra told Dow Jones Newswires. Misra said the company is seeking to acquire companies with staff strength of 500 to 2,000. "Aecom wants to have a staff of 3,000 in India, on its own or through acquisitions, in three years," he added. Aecom, which is currently a consultant in some metro rail and airport projects in India, has its own staff of 200. Earlier this week, it bought over a Delhi-based engineering consultancy firm, Spectral Services, with a total staff of 550. content: Foot Locker reports quarterly profit of $57 mln (4:52 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Foot Locker Inc. FL, +1.70% late Wednesday reported its fourth-quarter profit rose to $57 million, or 36 cents a share, from $23 million, or 14 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluding charges, the athletic retailer would have earned 39 cents a share. Revenue edged up to $1.39 billion from $1.33 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had projected the company to earn 36 cents a share on revenue of $1.37 billion. Collective Brands reports loss of $10.1 mln (4:13 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Collective Brands PSS late Wednesday reported a fourth-quarter loss attributable to the company of $10.1 million, or 16 cents a share, compared to a loss of $10.9 million, or 17 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue increased 4.3% to $773.8 million. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had forecast the parent of Payless ShoeSource and Stride Rite to report a loss of 18 cents a share on revenue of $764.4 million. B&G Foods avoids commodities crunch this year (11:27 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- B&G Foods BGS, -2.47% shares jumped 14% to $17.10 in late morning trades Wednesday as the Cream of Wheat maker looks on track to sidestep the agricultural commodities squeeze hitting many food companies. "Helped by timely hedging on key commodities such as wheat, B&G's 2011 cost inflation is expected to be only 1% of net sales--far lower than most food peers," RBC analyst Ed Aaron said in a research note. B&G posted an adjusted profit of 29 cents a share for the fourth quarter. Analysts had forecast 20 cents, according to FactSet Research. Gross margin rose to 33.2% of sales from 27.2% in the year-ago period, thanks to lower a lower commodities bill. Also Wednesday, Longbow Research upped its stock price target on B&G to $18, from $15. B&G shares are up 80 over last 12 months. Calavo Growers shares drop after profit miss (10:54 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Calavo Growers CVGW, +1.04% shares dropped 7% to $21.32 early Wednesday after the supplier of avocados and refrigerated fresh salsa reported a smaller profit than analysts expected. For the quarter ended Jan. 31, Santa Ana, Calif.-based Calavo posted a profit of 16 cents a share. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had forecast a profit of 25 cents a share. Calavo said its profit was hit by higher fruit and production costs. During the recent quarter, the food company also said it spent money to bolster its manufacturing safety. Calavo said it is "vigorously pursuing" acquisitions as it seeks to boost its line up of fresh produce. Calavo shares are up 15% over last 12 months. Energy stocks flat in early action (9:40 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Energy stocks caught their breath Wednesday after big losses in the previous session. The NYSE Arca Oil Index XOI, +2.04% rose 0.2% to 1,348. The NYSE Arca Natural Gas Index XNG, +2.25% fell 0.3% to 660. The Philadelphia Oil Service Index OSX, +2.53% traded unchanged at 283. Weatherford International WFT, +0.88% dropped 14% to $20.14. PPL Corp. PPL, +0.43% rose 3.5%. EOG Resources EOG, +1.40% fell 2%. BJ's net income falls on store closing costs (7:20 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- BJ's Wholesale Club Inc. BJ said Wednesday its fourth-quarter net income fell to $10.2 million, or 19 cents a share, from $54.5 million, or $1 a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted net income totaled 95 cents a share in the latest quarter, excluding costs for store closings. Revenue rose 7% to $2.9 billion, from $2.7 billion. Wall Street analysts expected BJ's to earn 92 cents a share, on revenue of $2.9 billion, according to a survey by FactSet Research. BJ's expects to earn 54 to 58 cents a share in the first quarter, and $2.62 a share to $2.82 a share in 2011. Analysts forecasted BJ's to earn 52 cents a share in the first quarter and $2.85 a share for the year. Separately, BJ's said its same-store sales rose 2.4% in February, excluding gasoline. "Severe winter storms had a negative impact on merchandise comparable club sales of 1% to 1.5%," the company said. Staples profit up 17% on lower tax rate (6:18 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Office products retailer Staples Inc. SPLS said Wednesday that its fiscal fourth-quarter net profit rose 17% to $274.7 million, or 38 cents a share, from $233.9 million, or 32 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the quarter was essentially flat at $6.42 billion against $6.41 billion a year earlier. Staples said a lower-than-expected effective tax rate added around 6 cents a share to its earnings due to the extension of provisions that allow for the deferral of tax on some foreign earnings. Adjusted earnings for the quarter ended Jan. 29 were 39 cents a share. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had been expecting earnings of 41 cents a share for the quarter on sales of $6.46 billion. For the current fiscal year, Staples said it expects to earn between $1.50 and $1.60 a share, which includes non-operating items that are likely to add between 5 cents and 6 cents a share to earnings. Analysts had been forecasting earnings of $1.55 a share for the year. Aecom expects charge to net on Libya withdrawal (4:48 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Aecom Technology Corp., ACM, +2.59% the Los Angeles provider of technical- and management-support services to companies and governments, said late on Tuesday that it had pulled all its expatriate employees out of Libya. The move should cut 8 cents a share from fiscal-second-quarter earnings, but the company also affirmed its full-year forecast of profit ranging from $2.25 to $2.35 a share. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research pegs the year's profit at $2.35. Since 2008, Aecom said, it's managed the Libyan Housing and Infrastructure Board's program to modernize the country's infrastructure. Given the current demonstrations seeking to oust Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi, Aecom can't right now say when or whether that program will resume. Costco net up 16%, comparable sales rose 7% (3:58 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Costco Wholesale Corp., COST, +2.63% the Issaquah, Wash., warehouse retailer, reported fiscal-second-quarter net income rose 16% as total sales rose 11% and comparable sales rose 7%. For the quarter ended Feb. 13, earnings reached $348 million, or 79 cents a share, from $299 million, or 67 cents, in the year-earlier quarter. The year-earlier share number included a 3-cent charge tied to employee benefits. Net sales rose 11% to $20.45 billion; total revenue, adding in membership fees, rose a similar percentage to $20.88 billion. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced consensus estimates of 79 cents a share of profit on $20.4 billion of sales. The comparable-sales figure reflects increases of 5% in the U.S. and 12% internationally, Costco said in a Wednesday statement. Excluding positive effects from higher gasoline prices and stronger foreign currencies, comparable sales rose 4%. In February, Costco net sales rose 14% to $6.38 billion while comparable sales rose 8%. Holcim 2010 profit falls 21%; sees sales up in '11 (3:06 AM ET) MADRID (MarketWatch) -- Swiss-based cement group Holcim Ltd.(CH:HOLN)on Wednesday reported net attributable profit fell 21% to 1.18 billion Swiss francs ($1.27 billion), against profit of CHF1.47 billion in the year-ago period as activity in the construction sector leveled out in the latter half of the year. Net sales rose 2.5% to CHF21.65 billion against CHF21.13 billion in the year-ago period. On a like-for-like basis, sales fell 2.1%. Analysts polled by Dow Jones Newswire were forecasting net profit of CH1.09 billion on sales of CHF21.88 billion. Operating earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization fell 2.5% to CHF4.51 billion -- analysts were expecting a 2.6% fall. For 2011, Holcim said uncertainty remains over some areas of the global economy, but it expects construction in mature markets will recover and emerging-markets growth will continue. It expects a rise in sales across all segments and will counter production and distribution costs by "vigorously pursuing price rises." ITV plans to resume dividend as profit triples (2:49 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. television group ITV PLC(UK:ITV)said Wednesday that it will restore dividend payments in July as it also said net profit for 2010 nearly tripled to 269 million pounds ($437 million) from 91 million pounds a year earlier. Revenue for the period rose 9.8% to 2.06 billion pounds and the group said it had also sharply reduced its net debt to 188 million pounds from 612 million pounds a year earlier. "Last year we set out a comprehensive five-year plan for the transformation of ITV. In this first phase, our outperformance of the television advertising market -- together with the actions taken to reduce the group's cost base and the focus on cash generation -- have delivered substantial debt reduction and a sound financial platform for the challenges ahead," said CEO Adam Crozier. Adidas net profit falls 64%; headwinds for 2011 (2:32 AM ET) MADRID (MarketWatch) -- German sportswear maker Adidas AG(DE:ADS)on Wednesday reported a fourth-quarter net profit of €7 million ($9.6 million), a 64% fall against profit of €19 million in the year-ago period as operating expenses rose. Net sales for the group rose 19% to €2.93 billion, against year-ago sales of €2.46 billion. Stripping out positive currency effects, Adidas said net sales rose 9%. Analysts polled by Dow Jones Newswires were forecasting net profit of €12.5 million on sales of €2.75 billion. Operating expenses for the group rose 21% to €1.38 billion. Gross margin rose 0.3 percentage point to 46.5% in the fourth quarter. In 2011, Adidas forecasts its gross margin roughly in line with the prior year, with earnings per share to rise to between €2.98 and €3.12. While gross margin at the retail level is expected to improve in 2011, helped by retail and Reebok brand improvements, the company sees sourcing costs rising "significantly," compared with the prior year, pressured by rising raw-material costs and capacity constraints. Hedge terms in 2011 are also likely to be less favorable, it said. Adidas is recommending a dividend of €0.80 for 2010, against €0.35 in 2009. Whitbread sales rise 12% (2:26 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. hotel and restaurant operator Whitbread PLC(UK:WTB)said Wednesday that total sales in the 11 weeks to Feb. 17 rose 12.4%, with comparable sales up 3.9%. "We anticipate that the outturn for the year will be in line with market expectations, demonstrating strong profit growth," said CEO Andy Harrison He added it is "premature to judge the trajectory of the U.K. consumer economy in 2011." Separately, Whitbread said it is buying self-serve coffee bar operator Coffee Nation for 59.5 million pounds ($96.6 million). St. Joe Q4 loss narrows to $2.7 million (12:57 AM ET) LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- St. Joe Co. JOE, -2.33% said early Wednesday its fourth-quarter loss narrowed to $2.7 million, or 3 cents a share, from a loss of $58.7 million, or 64 cents a share, in the same quarter a year before. Analysts had expected a loss on average of 9 cents a share, according to a FactSet Research survey. The Florida developer's revenue for the quarter totaled $37.1 million, flat with the year-ago period. content: Take-Two swings to profit for second quarter (4:01 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Take-Two Interactive Software said Tuesday afternoon that it swung to a profit for its second fiscal quarter on strong sales of its video game titles. "This is a significant milestone as we work to develop biotech traits that provide direct consumer benefits and solid results in the fields," DuPont said. The soybeans contain the highest oleic acid content of any soybean product under commercial development. Same-store sales rose 3.4% in the U.S., and 5.7% in Europe. Same-store sales in Asia/Pacific, Middle East and Africa rose 3.8%. DG, +0.66% said Tuesday its first-quarter net income increased by 64% to $136 million, or 39 cents a share, from $83 million, or 26 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted net income in the latest period totaled 42 cents a share. Sales grew by 11.9% to $3.11 billion. Wall Street analysts expected the Goodlettsville, Tenn. retailer to earn 34 cents a share, on revenue of $3.03 billion, according to a survey by FactSet Research. Aecom wins part of $3 billion Air Force contract (7:07 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Aecom Technology Corp. ACM, +2.59% said Tuesday it was one of 40 companies that won a five-year contract worth up to $3 billion for the U.S. Air Force Center for Engineering and the Environment. Aecom will provide environmental restoration and remediation services at the March Air Reserve Base in California. AECOM will also handle he remediation of surface soils at Wisconsin's General Mitchell Air Reserve Station. H&M cut at DB, consensus expectations too high (4:14 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Deutsche Bank on Tuesday cut its rating on Swedish apparel retailer Hennes & Mauritz(SE:HMB)to hold from buy, saying it expects the shares to trade sideways for the medium term as a result of unrealistic 2011 consensus expectations. "There is a clear risk that space expansion could surprise on the downside which, together with currency headwinds, would put pressure on earnings growth," the broker said in a note to clients. Still, Deutsche Bank stressed that its downgrade was "an absolute call" and that the headwinds faced by the company are largely applicable to the whole industry. Munich Re sees $1 billion cost from earthquake (2:50 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Reinsurance giant Munich Re(DE:MUV2)on Tuesday lifted its estimate for pretax losses from the Feb. 27 earthquake in Chile to around $1 billion. It had previously forecast that losses would be around $700 million. The company also said that it expects the total market loss for the insurance and reinsurance industry to be around $8 billion. The company said the first few months of 2010 were marked by a significantly large number of natural catastrophes. It anticipates a reinsurance claim of around 70 million euros for the storms that struck Europe at the end of February and has taken provisions of 160 million euros to cover the two hailstorms that occurred in Australia in March.
